questions.text: Which of the following spaces is not involved in the extravasation of blood following rupture of the penile urethra? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deep perineal pouch

 

Option B. Deep perineal pouch: This is a space situated superior to the perineal membrane and inferior to the pelvic diaphragm. It contains the membranous urethra, deep transverse perineal muscles, and parts of the external urethral sphincter. Extravasation of urine is possible in deep perineal pouch.

 

When there is a rupture of the penile urethra (often due to trauma, such as a straddle injury), the extravasation of urine and blood can occur into various anatomical spaces, depending on the location and nature of the injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial perineal pouch: This is a space located in the urogenital triangle of the perineum, bounded above by the perineal membrane and below by the perineal (Colles') fascia. The pouch contains the root of the penis (including the bulb of the penis) and the associated muscles. A rupture of the penile urethra can cause extravasation of urine and blood into this space.

 

Option C. Skin around penis. The skin around base of penis may get involved if the rupture is located in the bulbous part of urethra.

 

Option D. Skin around the scrotum: With a rupture of the penile urethra, especially if the rupture occurs in the bulbous part located within the superficial perineal pouch, the extravasated urine and blood can dissect through the fascial layers and present as swelling and bruising around the scrotum and base of the penis. This is often referred to as a "butterfly" pattern of bruising, as the extravasated fluid can spread anteriorly onto the anterior abdominal wall and laterally to the thighs but is typically limited superiorly by Scarpa's fascia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

The membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:  (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular bigeminy

 

Premature ventricular complex (PVCs)- Have following features

 

  • Broad QRS complex (>120ms) with abnormal morphology
  • Premature- i.e., occurs earlier than would be expected for the next sinus impulse
  • Discordant ST segment and T wave changes.
  • Usually followed by a full compensatory pause

 

PVCs often occur in repeating pattern: bigeminy, trigeminy, quadrigeminy

 

Couplet: 2 consecutive PVCs is known as couplet

 

Triplet: 3 consecutive PVCs is known as triplet

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia): This condition would show a fast, regular heart rate with narrow QRS complexes; not observed here.

 

Option C. P pulmonale: This involves peaked P waves seen in leads II, III, and aVF, typically due to right atrial enlargement; not evident in this ECG.

 

Option D. Re-entrant atrial fibrillation: Would show an irregularly irregular rhythm without consistent P waves; this is not present in the ECG provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular bigeminy is identified by the presence of alternating normal sinus beats and PVCs, each PVC typically followed by a compensatory pause, creating a repeating pattern of one normal beat followed by one abnormal beat.

choices.text: Making him sit in front row in class

questions.text: A child has bilateral SNHL. Which of the following is not preferred in the child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This procedure is primarily used to treat chronic adenoiditis and otitis media with effusion (OME), which are associated with conductive hearing loss (CHL), not SNHL. Since the child has SNHL, this treatment is not appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) indicates that there is a problem in the inner ear (cochlea) or the auditory nerve. When treating bilateral SNHL in a child, certain interventions are preferred based on the underlying pathology and the severity of the hearing loss.

 

Option A. Cochlear Implant: This is a viable option for children with severe to profound SNHL where the cochlea is affected but the auditory nerve is intact. The implant bypasses the damaged cochlea and directly stimulates the auditory nerve, allowing the child to hear.

 

Option C. Making him sit in front row in class: This is a common accommodation to help children with hearing loss to better hear and engage in classroom activities. It minimizes the distance between the child and the teacher, thus reducing the impact of hearing loss.

 

Option D.  Hearing Aid: This is suitable for children with mild to moderate SNHL. Hearing aids amplify sounds, making them louder and easier to hear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is not preferred for treating bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as it addresses conditions causing conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: The structure highlighted in green corresponds to which vertebral level in the anatomical position? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coccyx

 

The marked structure in the image is the ischial spine. In anatomical position, the ischial spine is located at the level of the coccyx. This is important in various medical procedures, including the pudendal nerve block, commonly used in obstetrics and gynecology. The ischial spine serves as a significant landmark for these procedures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L4: Incorrect. The L4 vertebra is located much higher in the vertebral column, around the lower back region, and is not associated with the ischial spine.

 

Option B. L4-L5: Incorrect. This option refers to the intervertebral disc space between L4 and L5, which is also in the lower back but not related to the pelvic region or ischial spine.

 

Option C. S3-S5: Incorrect. Although the ischial spine can be aligned with these sacral vertebrae in certain positions like lithotomy (during childbirth), but here the question is about anatomical position so this is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischial spine in anatomical position aligns with the coccyx, serving as an important landmark for various medical procedures.

choices.text: Start antibiotics and send samples for culture

questions.text: A patient who is intubated had an X-ray done. The radiograph is shown below. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ultrasound guided aspiration

 

Chest radiograph shows Unilateral Left pleural effusion. In the absence of suspicion for transudative effusion, thoracocentesis is indicated in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suction with percussion physiotherapy is recommended in suspected collapse due to mucus plugging etc.

 

Option B. Antibiotics are initiated if suspicion of severe CAP is present.

 

Option C. Chest physiotherapy is given to reduce collapse and pulmonary rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: 60-year-old lady presented with chest pain and exertional dyspnea. Her family says she was previously healthy and there was no similar disease in the family members. ECG on arrival is suggestive of Anterior wall MI. Her son succumbed to Severe COVID-19 pneumonia. CAG showed normal epicardial coronaries. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress.

 

Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure. Beta2 (Gs stimulation) at base and Beta2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimic ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. No signs of infection/Inflammation are given in the history. In presence of stress and temporal association, infection less likely.

 

Option C. Normal CAG rules out significant macrovascular CAD.

 

Option D. HCM shows dagger like q waves, SAM, Asymmetrical septal hypertrophy on ECHO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy can present with symptoms and ECG changes similar to those of an acute myocardial infarction, but it is distinguished by normal coronary arteries on angiography and is often precipitated by severe emotional stress, fitting the patient's recent personal history.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259.

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paralysis agitans

 

The substantia nigra is the marked structure in the transverse section of the brain that is shown. Degeneration of the substantia nigra is observed in Parkinson's disease, commonly referred to as paralysis agitans.

 

Due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which aid in the manufacture of dopamine, the substantia nigra is pigmented. The substantia nigra lacks or has less pigmentation in Parkinson's disease.

 

Parkinson's disease is characterized by bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors. It's also known as paralysis agitans due to the motor dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: Incorrect because depression is typically associated with dysfunctions in other brain regions such as the prefrontal cortex and limbic system, not specifically the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Alzheimer’s disease: Incorrect as Alzheimer's disease primarily involves the cerebral cortex and hippocampus, leading to amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, rather than specific damage to the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Huntington chorea: Incorrect because Huntington’s disease involves degeneration of the striatum and other parts of the brain but does not primarily affect the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra's degeneration is central to the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease, manifesting as motor symptoms like bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors.

questions.text: Based on the ECG given below, which of the following drugs is NOT used in the management of the condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine

 

The ECG shows a case of atrial fibrillation, characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and the absence of distinct P waves. Instead, there are fibrillatory waves that can be seen in the baseline. Atrial fibrillation is a common type of irregular heart rhythm where the atria beat chaotically and irregularly.

 

Adenosine is not used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It is primarily indicated for the treatment of regular narrow complex tachycardias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Adenosine works by temporarily blocking the atrioventricular (AV) node, which can help reset the heart rhythm in cases of regular tachycardias. However, in irregular rhythms like atrial fibrillation, adenosine is contraindicated because it can induce atrial fibrillation or exacerbate the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker used in the management of atrial fibrillation. It helps control the heart rate by slowing down the conduction through the AV node.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication used for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation. It can help to convert atrial fibrillation to a normal sinus rhythm and maintain it.

 

Option D. Diltiazem: Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to control the ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation by slowing conduction through the AV node.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenosine should not be used in the management of atrial fibrillation due to its potential to induce or worsen the condition.

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures in the correct sequence involved in the basal ganglia direct motor pathway: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

1. Striatum

2. Globus pallidus

3. Substantia nigra

4. Thalamus

5. Cortex
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5,1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

The correct sequence is as follows:

 

5. Cortex - provides the initial input to the basal ganglia.

 

1. Striatum - receives input from the cortex and is the first structure in the basal ganglia circuitry.

 

2. Globus pallidus - receives inhibitory input from the striatum and projects to the thalamus.

 

3. Substantia nigra - provides dopaminergic input to the striatum.

 

4. Thalamus - receives excitatory input from the globus pallidus and projects back to the cortex to complete the loop.

 

The basal ganglia needs the input from the cortex in order to act. The first and last component of the pathway is always the cerebral cortex. 


The complete pathway is Cortex/ Thalamus/ brain stem to stratum, then to globus pallidus & substantia nigra then to thalamus and then back to cortex.


Hence out of the available options 5,1,2,3,4 is the best suitable.

 

 

 

The putamen is located laterally and the internal capsule is located medially to the pallidum. The striatum and subthalamic nuclei send fibres to it. It is the primary basal ganglia output to the thalamus and superior colliculus. Each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri contains the substantia nigra. Dopamine levels in the substantia nigra and striata are reduced in Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of structures in the direct pathway of the basal ganglia starts with the cortex and follows through the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and ends at the thalamus. This pathway is fundamental in processing motor signals, which is particularly relevant in understanding disorders like Parkinson’s disease.

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Continue treatment for another 2 years
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment
Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics

questions.text: A 16-year-old who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continue treatment for another 2 years

 

In cases of epilepsy, particularly in children and adolescents, the continuation of antiepileptic drug (AED) therapy after a period of being seizure-free is typically recommended for about 2 years. This recommendation is based on the need to stabilize neurological function and minimize the risk of recurrence. The decision to discontinue AEDs should consider factors such as the duration of being seizure-free, EEG findings, the type of epilepsy, and the individual’s neurological examination.

 

Rationale for Continuing Treatment:

 

  • Continuing AED treatment for at least 2 years after achieving seizure control helps ensure the stability of the condition and reduces the likelihood of seizure recurrence, especially during the critical developmental years of adolescence.
  • Recurrences are most common in the first 3 months after discontinuing AEDs, making a cautious approach necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop the treatment and follow up: This would be risky given the short period of seizure freedom (only 6 months). Stopping treatment prematurely may lead to recurrence.

 

Option C. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: This is typically considered after a longer period of seizure freedom, usually a minimum of 2 years, not just 6 months.

 

Option D. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: This is generally reserved for cases of refractory epilepsy where seizures cannot be controlled with multiple medications, which does not seem to be the case here based on the information provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-epileptics once initiated must be continued for a minimum period of 2 years. Decision to stop AED is considered if, seizure free > 2 years with normal MRI, EEG, seizure type.

 

Recurrences occur in the first 3 months of discontinuing AED.

 

Reference - Harrison principles of internal Medicine 21st edition Pg. 12076

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins

 

The correct answer is B, Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins. This combination is effective against Burkholderia cepacia, a pathogen known for its resistance to many standard antibiotics. The standard regimen includes Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), which has broad-spectrum bacterial coverage, combined with a 3rd generation cephalosporin such as ceftazidime or cefoperazone-sulbactam to cover for the pathogen's unique resistance profiles and aggressive infection nature, especially in immunocompromised patients or those with existing cardiac issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminoglycoside and colistin: This option is incorrect due to the intrinsic resistance of Burkholderia cepacia to aminoglycosides. While colistin could still be effective, the resistance to aminoglycosides limits this combination's usefulness.

 

Option C. Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporin: Incorrect because the combination of carbapenems with cephalosporins is generally not recommended. They both share a similar mechanism of action, inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis, and could potentially compete for the same binding sites, thus reducing their effectiveness.

 

Option D. Cefepime and tigecycline: Incorrect because tigecycline is not particularly effective against Burkholderia cepacia. Cefepime alone would not sufficiently manage the infection due to the bacteria's robust resistance profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard regimen for Burkholderia cepacia is cotrimoxazole with ceftazidime /cefoperazone-sulbactam.

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Hypokalemia

2.Hypochloremia

3.Metabolic alkalosis

4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea can lead to multiple metabolic abnormalities: Hypokalemia, Hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

1. Hypokalemia: Loss of potassium through vomiting and diarrhea.

 

2. Hypochloremia: Loss of chloride.

 

3. Metabolic alkalosis: Loss of gastric acids.

 

These changes are due to the loss of electrolytes and fluids.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Respiratory alkalosis involves hyperventilation and a decrease in carbon dioxide, which is unrelated to the described condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is anatomically related to the region highlighted in green in the given image? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pudendal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in green is the ischial spine and the pudendal nerve is related to it.

 

The ischial spine is a bony projection from the posterior part of the ischium in the pelvis

 

The pudendal nerve originates from the sacral plexus S2-S4. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor by passing around the ischial spine. The ischial spine is used as a landmark for pudendal nerve block.

 

 

  1. Sensory function: The pudendal nerve provides sensation to the external genitalia, perineum, and anus.
  2. Motor function: The pudendal nerve also supplies motor function to the pelvic floor muscles, including the external anal sphincter, bulbospongiosus muscle, and ischiocavernosus muscle.
  3. Sexual function: The pudendal nerve plays a crucial role in sexual function by supplying motor and sensory innervation to the genital organs.
  4. Urinary and fecal continence: The pudendal nerve is involved in maintaining urinary and fecal continence by controlling the external anal sphincter muscle. Damage to the pudendal nerve can lead to incontinence, which is the loss of control over urinary or fecal elimination.Top of Form

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and originates from the sacral plexus (L4-S3). It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, below the piriformis muscle. While it is near the ischial spine, it descends posteriorly down the thigh, dividing into the tibial and common fibular (peroneal) nerves. It provides motor and sensory innervation to the posterior thigh and most of the leg and foot. Its relation to the ischial spine is less clinically significant than the pudendal nerve's.

 

Option C. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4). It exits the pelvis through the obturator foramen and provides sensory and motor innervation to the medial thigh. In terms of its relationship to the ischial spine, it is anatomically distinct, as it courses more anteriorly in the pelvis, and it doesn't have significant clinical associations with the ischial spine.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve also originates from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4). It descends through the psoas muscle and enters the thigh beneath the inguinal ligament. It provides motor innervation to the anterior thigh muscles and sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. The femoral nerve's course is anterior in the pelvis, and it doesn't have a direct relationship or significant clinical association with the ischial spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pudendal nerve arises from the sacral plexus (S2-S4 nerve roots). It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, just inferior to the piriformis muscle. It then courses around the ischial spine and re-enters the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen. The pudendal nerve provides sensory and motor innervation to the perineal region and external genitalia. Due to its proximity to the ischial spine, the pudendal nerve can be blocked for pain relief during childbirth and certain surgical procedures in the perineal region.

choices.text: The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.
The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen.
The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance.
The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the adrenal glands?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

 

 

  • The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape: This statement is false. The right adrenal gland is actually pyramidal in shape. The left adrenal gland is semi-lunar (crescent-shaped) in shape. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen: This statement is true. The left adrenal gland is anatomically positioned near the tail of the pancreas and the spleen.

 

Option C. The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance: This statement is true. The adrenal glands have a yellowish appearance on gross examination due to their rich lipid content.

 

Option D. The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location: This statement is true. The adrenal glands, like the kidneys, are retroperitoneal, meaning they are located behind the peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The right adrenal gland is pyramidal in shape, while the left adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 -1 - 3 - 4- 5

 

The auditory pathway begins at the peripheral sensory receptors and progresses through a series of nuclei and tracts in the central nervous system before reaching the auditory cortex. The correct sequence from the periphery to the higher centers is:

 

  • Spiral ganglion (2): Located in Rosenthal's canal within the cochlea, the spiral ganglion contains bipolar neurons that send fibers through the cochlear nerve (part of the eighth cranial nerve) to the brainstem.
  • Cochlear nucleus (1): The first central auditory nucleus where the cochlear nerve fibers terminate.
  • Superior olivary nucleus (3): Serves as a major binaural processing center in the brainstem, crucial for localizing sounds in space.
  • Inferior colliculus (4): Acts as an important relay station in the midbrain, integrating auditory input before sending it to the thalamus.
  • Medial geniculate body (5): Part of the thalamus, this structure further processes auditory information before transmitting it to the auditory cortex.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve

  2. Cochlear Nucleus

  3. Superior Olivary nucleus

  4. Lateral lemniscus

  5. Inferior colliculus

  6. Medial geniculate body

  7. Auditory cortex

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 15

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

APML is a leukemia with excellent prognosis managed with Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by infiltrates, pleural effusion after treatment and improves with Dexamethasone. Used Intrathecally in children for AML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine is used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin is a cardiotoxic drug used in Hodgkin, CA breast, thyroid.

 

Option D. Methotrexate is not recommended in APML treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs.

 

Reference -Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: The SRY gene is located in which of the following chromosomal regions? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Short arm of Y chromosome

 

Explanation

 

  • The SRY gene is located on the short arm (p-arm) of the Y chromosome (Yp11). This gene is often referred to as the "master switch" for male development. It codes for a transcription factor that triggers the development of testes in an embryo, which, in turn, leads to the development of male reproductive structures.

 

  • It is an intron less sex-determining gene on the Y chromosome.

 

 

 

Y- chromosome 

 

The SRY (Sex-determining Region Y) gene is a critical genetic region responsible for initiating male sex determination and the development of male reproductive organs in mammals, including humans. Let's discuss the location of the SRY region in detail for each option:

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Short arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not located on the X chromosome. It is specific to the Y chromosome and plays a pivotal role in male sex determination.

 

Option C) Long arm of Y chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not on the long arm (q-arm) of the Y chromosome. It is situated on the short arm, as mentioned earlier.

 

Option D) Long arm of X chromosome: Incorrect. The SRY gene is not present on the X chromosome. It is unique to the Y chromosome and is responsible for the differentiation of the bipotential gonad into the testis during early embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sex- determining region Y protein (SRY) gene or TDF ( Testis-determining factor ) is a DNA binding protein encoded by the SRY gene that is responsible for the initiation of male sex determination in mammals. Its expression causes the development of primary sex cords, which later develop into seminiferous tubules.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS Score in an intubated patient, with findings of eye movements to pain and abnormal flexion? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E2VNTM3.

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is used to assess the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury and other conditions. In this scenario, the patient is intubated, which affects the ability to assess the verbal response. The current nomenclature for denoting non-testability due to intubation is "NT" (Non-testable) for the verbal component.

 

  • Eye Opening (E): The patient opens eyes in response to painful stimuli, which scores 2.
  • Verbal Response (V): The verbal component is non-testable (NT) due to intubation.
  • Motor Response (M): The patient exhibits abnormal flexion (decorticate response), which scores 3.

 

This combination gives a GCS score of E2VNTM3.

 

 

NT = non-testability of the corresponding component.

 

Used mainly in acute TBI (Traumatic brain injury).

 

Update:

 

1. GCS-P Score takes pupillary activity into consideration.

 

P = Pupillary non-reactivity

 

2 = Both pupil

 

1 = One pupil

 

0 = None

 

Minimum = 1, Max = 15.

 

2. FOUR score (Full outline of unresponsiveness) is currently employed having better sensitivity, specificity and PPV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In intubated patients, the GCS verbal score is marked as "NT" for non-testable. The GCS remains a vital tool in assessing the level of consciousness, particularly in emergency and critical care settings, ensuring that changes in the patient’s neurological status are promptly recognized and appropriately managed.

 

Reference - Harrison/Neurology/Basics /Chapter 443-TBI

questions.text: In the provided lateral view of the skull, the region indicated by the arrow overlies which of the following intracranial structures? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stem of lateral sulcus

 

The marked structure in the image is the pterion, which is an H-shaped area on the lateral side of the skull where four bones meet (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid). The central part of the pterion is called the Sylvian point. Deep to the pterion lies the stem of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) of the brain. The pterion is a clinically important landmark because the middle meningeal artery runs directly beneath it, and injury to this area can cause extradural hemorrhage, which appears as a biconvex opacity on radiological imaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ICA Siphon: Incorrect because the internal carotid artery (ICA) siphon is located deeper in the skull, within the cavernous sinus, not directly beneath the pterion.

 

Option C. Wernicke's area: Incorrect because Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus (area 22) of the dominant hemisphere, not directly deep to the pterion.

 

Option D. Pineal gland: Incorrect because the pineal gland is located at the center of the brain in the epithalamus, not related to the pterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H-shaped area on the lateral skull where four bones meet (frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid), and it overlies the stem of the lateral sulcus and middle meningeal artery.

questions.text: Nadas criteria include all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Raised Trop T level

 

Nadas criteria, proposed by Hungarian cardiologist Dr. Alexander Nadas in the 1950s–60s, are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease. The criteria require at least one major and two minor criteria for diagnosis. Major criteria include systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, presence of congestive heart failure, and cyanosis. Minor criteria include grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal chest X-ray, abnormal ECG, and abnormal blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nadas criteria are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease, which includes both major criteria (systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, CCF, cyanosis) and minor criteria (grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal X-ray, abnormal ECG, abnormal BP).

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trismus

 

  • Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space.
  • Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by styloid process & its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vocal cord palsy: This could manifest due to involvement of the cranial nerves (CN IX, X, XI, XII) that are located in the post-styloid compartment. CN X (vagus nerve) palsy particularly can lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option C. Parotid swelling: Swelling in this region may occur as the post-styloid compartment is adjacent to the parotid gland and includes inflammatory processes that might extend into the parotid space.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: This syndrome may appear if the sympathetic chain, which runs through the post-styloid compartment, is affected by an infection or its related inflammatory processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presentation in a post-styloid abscess:

 

Bulge behind posterior tonsillar pillar.

 

  • Since post styloid compartment contains CN IX, X, XI, XII, their palsies may be seen.
  • Sympathetic chain involvement in this compartment will cause Horner's syndrome.
  • Swelling of the parotid region
  • No trismus or minimal trismus
  • General Symptoms - Fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (due to spasm of prevertebral muscles) and signs of toxemia

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Contrast-enhanced CT scan neck – for extent of a lesion.
  • Magnetic resonance arteriography is useful if thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery is suspected.

 

Treatment

 

  • IV antibiotics with aerobic and anaerobic cover
  • Incision and drainage of abscess

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scalp, dura, arachnoid

 

Explanation:

 

The arrow in the illustration, which displays a baby's skull, is pointing in the direction of the anterior fontanelle. Ventricular tapping is the term used to describe the process of removing CSF from the anterior fontanelle. The various structures pierced are the scalp, dura, and arachnoid.

 

Fontanelle tap/ Percutaneous ventricular puncture:

 

Infants who need urgent ventricular decompression and have an open anterior fontanelle and no access to a VP shunt undergo a fontanelle tap or percutaneous ventricular puncture. A butterfly needle is used to immediately puncture the infant's open fontanelle and enter the lateral ventricle in order to obtain CS samples, alleviate pressure, or insert a drain or catheter.

 

Procedure: A 25-gauge butterfly needle is inserted through the anterolateral aspect of the anterior fontanelle (away from the midline, avoiding the superior sagittal sinus).

 

When performing a fontanelle tap, the following layers are pierced:

 

  • Scalp: This includes the skin and the underlying connective tissue of the scalp.
  • Membranous fontanelle: The actual fontanelle is a soft spot on a baby's head where the bones of the skull have not yet fused together. It's a membranous gap between the cranial bones.
  • Dura mater: The tough outermost membrane of the three layers of the meninges that surround the brain and spinal cord.
  • Arachnoid mater: A thin, wispy layer that lies underneath the dura mater.
  • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF): Once through the arachanoid mater, the needle enters the subarachnoid space where the CSF is located.

 

Note: The fontanelle tap bypasses the bony skull, which is why it's an accessible route in neonates and infants for procedures that require access to the CSF. However, as the child grows, these fontanelles close, and the method is no longer viable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fontanelle tap is a critical emergency procedure used in infants for CSF sampling or pressure relief from the ventricles, exploiting the unossified sections of the skull for direct access to the CSF. This procedure is unique to neonates and young infants where the fontanelle is present and typically involves piercing the scalp, dura, and arachnoid layers.

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen rotundum

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the sphenoid bone. The foramen marked is the foramen rotundum. Maxillary branch of trigeminal nerve passes through it.

 

 

The foramen rotundum is a small circular opening in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, located in the middle cranial fossa of the skull. It serves as a passage for the maxillary nerve (CN V2), which is one of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve.

 

The maxillary nerve exits the cranial cavity through the foramen rotundum and then travels through the pterygopalatine fossa, where it gives off several branches that innervate the maxillary teeth, the maxillary sinus, and the skin of the face in the maxillary region.

 

Other structures that may pass through the foramen rotundum include small blood vessels and veins, but these are less significant than the maxillary nerve in terms of clinical relevance.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Foramen Ovale:

 

  • Location: The foramen ovale is also located in the sphenoid bone, adjacent (Postero- lateral) to the foramen rotundum.
  • Contents: It transmits the mandibular nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve or CN V3), the accessory meningeal artery, and sometimes a small emissary vein.

 

Option C. Vidian Canal (Pterygoid Canal):

 

  • Location: The vidian canal is a small canal in the sphenoid bone, extending from the pterygopalatine fossa to the middle cranial fossa.
  • Contents: It contains the vidian nerve, which is a branch of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), as well as the vidian artery and sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • Location: The foramen spinosum is situated in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It is present postero-lateral to foramen ovale
  • Contents: It transmits the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, and the middle meningeal vein.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During femoral vein catheterization, local anesthesia administered just below the inguinal ligament primarily blocks which of the following nerves? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Genitofemoral nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Genitofemoral nerve is blocked when the local anesthetic is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization.

 

The genitofemoral nerve is a mixed nerve that arises from the anterior divisions of the L1 and L2 spinal nerves. It descends through the psoas major muscle and emerges from the lateral border of the muscle. It then divides into two branches: The genital branch, which supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the mons pubis, labia majora or scrotum, and cremaster muscle in males.

 

The femoral branch, which passes laterally over the iliacus muscle and descends along the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle. It supplies sensory fibers to the skin of the femoral triangle and the upper anterior thigh.

 

In addition to its sensory functions, the genitofemoral nerve also provides motor innervation to the cremaster muscle in males, which raises the testes towards the body in response to cold or other stimuli. Dysfunction of the genitofemoral nerve can lead to sensory loss or motor weakness in the areas it innervates.

 

 

During femoral vein catheterization, local anesthesia is typically administered in the area inferior to the inguinal ligament and close to the femoral pulse. Among the given options, the genitofemoral nerve is the one most likely to be anesthetized during this procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is the largest branch of the lumbar plexus and arises from the dorsal divisions of the ventral rami of the L2-L4 spinal nerves. It descends through the iliopsoas muscle and enters the femoral triangle, lateral to the femoral vessels. The femoral nerve primarily supplies muscles in the anterior compartment of the thigh and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. While it is in close proximity to the femoral vein, it is not the primary nerve targeted during femoral vein catheterization.

 

Option C. Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh: This nerve originates from the L2-L3 levels of the lumbar plexus. It travels inferiorly and exits the pelvis under the inguinal ligament, close to the anterior superior iliac spine, to supply the skin on the lateral aspect of the thigh. While it is near the inguinal ligament, its location is more lateral compared to the site of femoral vein catheterization, making it less likely to be affected.

 

Option D. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve arises from the L1 level of the lumbar plexus. It travels through the inguinal canal and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the groin, mons pubis, and scrotum or labium majus. The course and distribution of this nerve make it less relevant for femoral vein catheterization, which occurs more medially and inferiorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genitofemoral nerve arises from the L1-L2 levels of the lumbar plexus. It descends on the anterior surface of the psoas major muscle and then splits into two branches: the genital and femoral branches. The femoral branch pierces the fascia lata to provide sensory innervation to a small area of skin over the femoral triangle. Given its anatomical location and course, this nerve is likely to be anesthetized during femoral vein catheterization.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common cause of bipedal edema? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Venous Insufficiency

 

Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) typically leads to asymmetric leg swelling, where one leg is more affected than the other. In cases of CVI, the swelling is often unilateral, and if bilateral, it is usually asymmetric. This makes it the least common cause of bipedal (symmetric) edema among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lupus Nephritis: This condition affects the kidneys, leading to fluid retention and typically causing bilateral leg swelling. It is a common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option C. Heart Failure: This systemic condition causes the heart to pump blood inefficiently, leading to fluid buildup in the lower extremities and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option D. Chronic Liver Disease: This condition results in decreased protein synthesis and portal hypertension, causing fluid retention and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic venous insufficiency typically causes unilateral or asymmetric leg swelling, making it the least common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

questions.text: Identify the blue line shown in the below picture:(AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ohngren's line

 

  • Ohngren's line is an imaginary line passing through the medial canthus of the eye and angle of mandible.
  • It is used for classification of maxillary carcinoma.
  • Growth situated above the plane - Suprastructure - Poor Prognosis
  • Growth situated below the plane - Infrastructure - Good Prognosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frankfurt horizontal line, the line passing through the inferior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal, is one of the most widely used intracranial landmarks in cephalometric analysis.

 

 

Option B. Donaldson line is an imaginary line drawn posteriorly from the course of the horizontal semicircular canal, used to identify endolymphatic sac during endolymphatic sac decompression surgery for meniere’s disease.

 

 

Option C. According to Lederman’s classification, 2 horizontal lines called lines of Sebileau pass through orbit floor and maxillary sinus, producing Suprastructure, mesostructure and infrastructure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ohngren's line is used to classify maxillary carcinomas into suprastructure and infrastructure based on their location relative to the line, which is critical for determining the prognosis and approach for surgical intervention.

questions.text: Management of hyperkalemia includes all except : (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Magnesium sulphate

 

Magnesium sulfate is not typically used for the treatment of hyperkalemia. It is more commonly used in the management of eclampsia in pregnant women and for its neuromuscular blocking effects in various other medical conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

The management of hyperkalemia typically involves interventions that stabilize the cardiac membrane, shift potassium into cells, and remove potassium from the body. Common treatments include:

 

Option A. Calcium gluconate: Which stabilizes the cardiac membrane and does not lower potassium levels but protects the heart from the effects of hyperkalemia.

 

Option B. Insulin drip: Often accompanied by glucose, which drives potassium back into cells, thereby lowering its serum concentration.

 

Option  C. Salbutamol nebulization: A beta-agonist that promotes the movement of potassium into cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of hyperkalemia

 

  • Calcium gluconate- reduces plasma K+ concentration by redistribution in cells rapidly
  • Insulin- lowers plasma K+ concentration by moving potassium intracellular, insulin dose used – 10units of IV regular insulin f/b 50ml of 50%dextrose
  • Salbutamol
  • Cation exchange resins, diuretics, dialysis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypercalcemia 

 

Tumor lysis syndrome occurs due to destruction of large no of rapidly proliferating neoplstic cells. It is characterised by Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia , hyperphosphasphatemia, hypocalcemia, acidosis, acute renal failure.

 

It mainly occurs after initiation of chemotherapy and is diagnosed by Cairo bishop criteria (includes both lab and clinical features)

 

Management includes - allopurinol , rasburicase along with aggressive hydration .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperphosphatemia: Typically occurs as phosphate is released from lysed tumor cells.

 

Option B. Hyperuricemia: Results from the metabolism of nucleic acids from destroyed cells.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: Occurs due to the release of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space.

 

Educational Objective:


In tumor lysis syndrome, the rapid breakdown of tumor cells leads to hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, making this the key distinguishing feature in identifying the condition. Management strategies like hydration, use of allopurinol, or rasburicase are critical in preventing renal failure and other serious complications.

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is due to which of the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asthenospermia

 

Asthenospermia (Immotile sperm [Greek sthenos = strength]

 

Kartagener result from loss of function of axonemal dynein that impairs sperm motility. Respiratory Ciliary dysmotility leads to bronchiectasis and recurrent infections. Association of situs inversus is noted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oligospermia: Incorrect because while sperm count can be affected in some genetic or hormonal disorders, in Kartagener's syndrome, the sperm count is typically normal; the issue lies in their motility.

 

Option C. Epididymis obstruction: Incorrect as this is not a feature of Kartagener’s syndrome. While structural anomalies in the reproductive tract can lead to such issues, Kartagener’s syndrome specifically affects the motility of sperm due to ciliary dysfunction.

 

Option D. Undescended testes: Incorrect as undescended testes are not associated with Kartagener’s syndrome, which primarily affects ciliary function and not the anatomical position of the testes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is primarily due to asthenospermia, which is caused by the immobility of sperm. This immotility results from the genetic defect affecting the dynein arm of sperm flagella, similar to the defect affecting cilia in the respiratory tract, leading to the classic symptoms of the syndrome.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Bronchiectasis/Chapter 290

questions.text: A patient develops paralysis of the lower lip following a parotidectomy. Which branch of the facial nerve was most likely injured? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

The cervical branch of the facial nerve is responsible for innervating the platysma muscle, which is crucial for controlling lower lip movements. During a parotidectomy, if this branch is damaged, it can lead to paralysis of the lower lip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid duct: The parotid duct is not a part of the facial nerve. It is a salivary duct and does not contribute to nerve innervation.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead, including the frontalis, corrugator supercilii, and orbicularis oculi. It does not affect lower lip movements.

 

Option D. Main trunk of facial nerve: The main trunk of the facial nerve divides into several branches, including the temporal and cervical branches. It is not directly responsible for the lower lip movement, as it provides the general innervation before splitting into specific branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the cervical branch of the facial nerve during a parotidectomy can result in lower lip paralysis.

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior nucleus

 

The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is where the fibres from the mamillary body, which is the structure seen in the above figure, terminate.

 

The third ventricle's floor is made up of two tiny, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences called mammillary bodies, which are arranged side by side. The anterior thalamic nucleus receives fibres from the medial mammillary nucleus.

 

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions -anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

 

  • Major input: Mammillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus.
  • Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus
  • Major function:
    • Regulation of alertness and attention
    • Acquisition of memory

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior nucleus: The posterior nuclear group, also known as the pulvinar, is the largest nuclear group in the thalamus. It is involved in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the posterior nucleus.

 

Option B. Reticular nucleus: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus surrounds the lateral aspect of the thalamus and serves as a modulator of information transfer between different parts of the thalamus and the cerebral cortex. It primarily functions to regulate the activity of relay nuclei in the thalamus. While it plays an important role in modulating thalamic function, the mammillothalamic tract does not primarily terminate here.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral nucleus: The ventral lateral nucleus is one of the principal relay nuclei of the thalamus that receives inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia and projects to the primary motor cortex. It is involved in the coordination and planning of movements. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the ventral lateral nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus is involved in emotional tone and recent memory. Fibers from the mammillary bodies, via the mammillothalamic tract, terminate in the anterior nuclei of the thalamus. The connection between the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nucleus is a crucial part of the Papez circuit.

questions.text: Components of the MELD (2016) score are all except? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Albumin

 

The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation and assesses the severity of chronic liver disease. The MELD score includes three laboratory values:

 

“CBI mnemonic = Creatinine, Bilirubin, INR are the parameters is MELD score.

 

Currently Sodium levels to the score and MELD-Na score used for prognostication. Hyponatremia associated with adverse outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Reflects the liver's ability to excrete bilirubin.

 

Option C. INR (International Normalized Ratio) for prothrombin time: Indicates the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors.

 

Option D. Creatinine: Assesses renal function, which can be compromised in liver failure. Additionally, sodium was added to the MELD score to improve its prognostic accuracy, resulting in the MELD-Na score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albumin is not a component of the MELD score. The key components are bilirubin, creatinine, and INR, with sodium also included in the updated MELD-Na scoring system to better predict outcomes in patients with end-stage liver disease.

 

Reference: Harrison 21/Cirrhosis/Chap 344

questions.text: The Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing which of the following conditions? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute severe ulcerative colitis

 

The Truelove and Witt criteria are specifically used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis. These criteria help classify the disease into mild, moderate, or severe categories.


Another set of criteria called the Travis criteria is used to assess treatment response and predict the risk of progression to surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalitis: Incorrect because encephalitis has its own specific diagnostic criteria and severity assessment tools that focus on neurological symptoms and findings.

 

Option C. ARDS: Incorrect because ARDS is diagnosed and classified using the Berlin criteria (2012), which primarily use the P/F ratio (PaO2/FiO2) with a PEEP of at least 5 cm H2O.

 

Option D. Acute pancreatitis: Incorrect because acute pancreatitis has scoring systems for severity assessment, such as Ranson's criteria or the APACHE II score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis.

 

Truelove and Witt's Criteria for Severity of Ulcerative Colitis

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liddle syndrome

 

Liddle syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the overactivation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the principal cells of the kidneys. This overactivation is due to a gain-of-function mutation in the genes encoding these channels. The increased activity of ENaC leads to excessive reabsorption of sodium and water, causing hypertension. Concurrently, there is increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, which results in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

 

This condition is often referred to as pseudo-hyperaldosteronism because it mimics the effects of aldosterone but without elevated aldosterone levels. The treatment of choice for Liddle syndrome is amiloride, which directly inhibits ENaC channels, unlike spironolactone, which is ineffective in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome also presents with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, but patients typically have normal blood pressure. It is a group of autosomal recessive disorders that affect the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, mimicking the effects of loop diuretics. Symptoms often present in childhood and may include polyuria, polydipsia, and growth delays. Additionally, patients might have nephrocalcinosis due to increase urinary calcium, recurrent urinary stones, and sometimes sensorineural deafness.

 

Option C. Gitelman syndrome: Gitelman syndrome, like Bartter syndrome, involves hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis with normal blood pressure. It affects the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, similar to the action of thiazide diuretics. Patients usually present in adulthood with symptoms such as muscle weakness, cramps, and tetany due to hypomagnesemia, which is a significant feature distinguishing it from Bartter syndrome.

 

Option D. Gordon syndrome: Gordon syndrome, or pseudohypoaldosteronism type II, is characterized by hypertension and hyperkalemia, along with metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis. It results from mutations leading to increased sodium chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Unlike Liddle syndrome, patients with Gordon syndrome exhibit hyperkalemia and acidosis due to chloride retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liddle syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and hypertension due to the overactivation of epithelial sodium channels in the kidneys.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presented with fever and difficulty swallowing. He had swelling in the marked region and was advised to undergo surgery. Post-surgery the gauze continued to soak with blood. Which of the following vessels must have been injured? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Paratonsillar vein

 

Explanation:

 

In the case described, the patient likely underwent surgery for a peritonsillar abscess (aka Quinsy), a complication arising from tonsillitis. This condition can lead to significant swelling in the throat and difficulty swallowing. Post-operative bleeding in such cases, especially the continuous type noted as soaking through gauze, is most commonly associated with venous sources rather than arterial.

 

The given image is a cadaveric specimen with an arrow pointing to the tonsillar fossa. The paratonsillar / external palatine vein is the typical site of venous origin for post-tonsillectomy bleeding.

 

The paratonsillar vein, which is closely associated with the tonsillar bed and provides significant venous drainage for the tonsil, is the likely source of this bleeding. Venous bleeding tends to be continuous and can be persistent if the vein is not adequately secured during surgery.

 

Torrential hemorrhage can be due to injury to an aberrantly large or aberrantly placed tonsillar arterial branch of the facial artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery: The tonsils receive blood supply primarily from the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Injury to this artery during tonsillar surgery can cause bleeding, but the bleeding is usually brisk and bright red, and the artery would likely be cauterized or ligated during surgery to prevent such bleeding.

 

Option B. Ascending pharyngeal artery: It's a branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the pharynx, soft palate, and the tympanic cavity. While this artery does provide blood supply to the pharyngeal region, it's not as intimately associated with the tonsillar region as the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

 

Option D. Retromandibular vein: The retromandibular vein is formed by the union of the superficial temporal vein and the maxillary vein in the parotid gland. It's located further away from the tonsillar region, and it's unlikely to be injured during procedures involving the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood supply of the tonsils:

 

 

Arterial supply:

 

  • The tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the main supply.
  • Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery.

 

Venous supply:

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus.

 

Types of Hemorrhage seen during/post tonsillectomy:

 

1. Primary hemorrhage:

  • Occurs during surgery due to injury to blood vessels.
  • Can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

 

2. Reactionary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs within 24 hours of surgery.
  • It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or return of blood pressure to normal.
  • It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
  • If not controlled the patient is anesthetized and hemorrhage is managed by re-exploration.

 

3. Secondary hemorrhage:

  • It occurs between 24 hours to 10 days (most common between 5th to 8th postoperative days).
  • It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
  • The patient is started on IV antibiotics and if not controlled, general anesthesia is given and the bleeding vessel is electrocoagulated or ligated.

questions.text: A patient in emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray is shown below. In gram staining and culture only, rhinovirus was isolated. The patient is shifted to ICU. What is the treatment of choice in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin

 

The patient is diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and has been shifted to the ICU. The treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with CAP includes a beta-lactam antibiotic like beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor (BL/BLI) combination like amoxicillin-clavulanic acid or piperacillin-tazobactam, or a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone combined with azithromycin or a respiratory fluoroquinolone such as levofloxacin or moxifloxacin should be administered.

 

Ceftriaxone are used to cover typical bacteria, while azithromycin covers atypical bacteria and provides additional anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Azithromycin: Insufficient as monotherapy in ICU settings.
 

Option C. Amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid: Lacks coverage for atypical pathogens alone.
 

Option D. Piperacillin Tazobactam plus ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not a respiratory fluoroquinolone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of a beta-lactam antibiotic and azithromycin is the treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for hairy cell leukemia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cladribine

 

It is a purine analogue used in the treatment of Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Cladribine-phosphates interfere with DNA synthesis and repair through incorporation into DNA and through inhibition of enzymes involved in DNA metabolism, including DNA polymerase and ribonucleotide reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D are not used in Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia patients have mutation in BRAF pathway and hence, Vemurafenib (BRAF inhibitor) is used as second line agent in refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cladribine remains the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia due to its high efficacy in inducing remissions.

questions.text: Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve results in which of the following clinical manifestations? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of extension at finger

 

The posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) is the deep branch of the radial nerve that supplies most of the extensor muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm. When injured, it affects the extension of fingers because it directly supplies the extensor digitorum, which is responsible for finger extension. However, it does not supply three specific muscles of the posterior compartment: anconeus, brachioradialis, and extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRB) - these are supplied by the main radial nerve before it divides. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of supination: Incorrect because supination is performed by both the supinator muscle (supplied by PIN) and the biceps brachii (supplied by musculocutaneous nerve). Even with PIN injury, the biceps can still perform supination, especially in the semiflexed elbow position.

 

Option C. Loss of extension of wrist: Incorrect because some wrist extension is preserved due to the function of extensor carpi radialis longus, which is supplied by the radial nerve proper and not the posterior interosseous branch.

 

Option D. Wrist drop: Incorrect because complete wrist drop requires injury to the main radial nerve. In PIN injury, the extensor carpi radialis longus is spared, allowing some wrist extension to be maintained.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior interosseous nerve (deep branch of radial nerve) supplies all posterior compartment muscles except anconeus, brachioradialis, and extensor carpi radialis longus. Its injury results in finger extension loss while preserving partial wrist extension.

questions.text: Which of these options is not a causal factor for head and neck malignancies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Vitamin A deficiency is not recognized as a direct risk factor for head and neck malignancies. While vitamin A plays crucial roles in maintaining epithelial tissues and immune function, its deficiency primarily leads to issues like night blindness and immune deficiencies, rather than directly causing cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) infection: EBV is associated with various types of cancers, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It is a well-established risk factor for this specific type of head and neck cancer.

 

Option B. HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infection: HPV, particularly type 16, is a significant risk factor for oropharyngeal cancers. The virus can lead to cellular transformations that result in malignancy.

 

Option Betel nut: Consumption of betel nut, often part of a "paan" or betel quid, is a known risk factor for oral cancers, particularly in the gingivobuccal sulcus, common in regions where it is a cultural practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common risk factors known to cause head and neck malignancies includes:

 

  1. Alcohol use
  2. Tobacco use (smoking or chewing)
  3. Viruses
    1. HPV 16 - oropharyngeal cancer
    2. EBV – Nasopharyngeal cancer
  4. Paan (betel quid) – Oral cancers especially in gingivobuccal sulcus
  5. Preserved or salted food consumption - nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  6. Occupational exposure:
    1. Exposure to wood or nickel dust or formaldehyde - a risk factor for cancers of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
    2. Radiation exposure is a risk factor for salivary gland tumors, thyroid gland carcinoma

choices.text: Acute kidney injury (AKI)
Chronic renal failure

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

 

The AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease) criteria are specifically designed to classify and diagnose Acute Kidney Injury (AKI). These criteria help in early detection and grading the severity of AKI based on changes in serum creatinine, urine output, and duration of symptoms.

 

Current diagnosis is based on the KDIGO group criteria. Urine output (OR) Creatinine rise is considered in the diagnosis.

 

KDIGO group criteria for diagnosis of AKI:

 

  1. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 0.3mg/dL.
  2. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 1.5 times of baseline that is known/presumed to have occur in the past 7 days.
  3. Urine volume < 0.5ml/kg/hour for 6 hours.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute glomerulonephritis: This has specific clinical and laboratory features distinct from AKI.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: Characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over months to years.

 

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome: Defined by high levels of protein in the urine, low levels of protein in the blood, high levels of cholesterol, and swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AKIN and RIFLE criteria are essential tools for diagnosing and assessing the severity of Acute Kidney Injury, which can guide interventions and predict outcomes in affected patients. They emphasize changes in serum creatinine and urine output as key indicators of kidney function.

questions.text: The nerve supplying the structure indicated by the arrow in the given CT image arises from which level of the brainstem? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Red nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The medial rectus muscle is the one highlighted in the provided CT picture. The oculomotor nerve, whose nucleus is located at the level of the superior colliculus adjacent to the red nucleus, supplies the medial rectus.

 

The nuclear complex from which the oculomotor nerve arises consists of:

 

  • Several groups of large motor neurons are collectively called the oculomotor nucleus. The motor neuron groups of the oculomotor nucleus innervate, in dorsoventral order, the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus. A medially placed column of cells innervates the contralateral superior rectus.
  • Smaller preganglionic parasympathetic neurons called the Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subthalamic nuclei: The subthalamic nucleus is part of the diencephalon and is closely associated with the basal ganglia circuitry. It plays a role in motor control. It's not directly associated with the oculomotor nerve's origin.

 

Option C. Decussation of pyramidal tract: The decussation of the pyramidal tract (motor fibers) occurs in the lower medulla oblongata, well below the level of the oculomotor nerve's origin. This is where the majority of motor fibers from one hemisphere cross to the opposite side.

 

Option D. Olivary nucleus: The olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is primarily associated with the coordination of motor tasks. Again, it's located caudally relative to the oculomotor nerve's origin in the midbrain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the anterior aspect of the midbrain, at the level of the superior colliculus. Its nucleus is situated ventral to the cerebral aqueduct and in close proximity to the red nucleus. Hence, the oculomotor nerve is often associated with the level of the red nucleus in the midbrain. It exits the midbrain medial to the cerebral peduncle.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

The correct choice is B, Dexamethasone, because the symptoms described (fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates) suggest the patient may be experiencing differentiation syndrome, which can occur following the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) with agents like Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by such symptoms and can improve with the administration of Dexamethasone. Dexamethasone is also used intrathecally in children for treating Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), indicating its relevance in managing severe inflammatory reactions in hematological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine: This option is incorrect as Cytarabine is primarily used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia and not specifically indicated for the management of differentiation syndrome in APML.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin: Incorrect because Doxorubicin is utilized for its efficacy against various cancers including Hodgkin's disease, cancer of the breast, and thyroid but is not suitable for treating differentiation syndrome in APML. It is also known for its cardiotoxic effects.

 

Option D. Methotrexate: Incorrect as it is not recommended in the treatment regimen for APML and does not address the immediate complications of differentiation syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs

 

Reference - Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: A 22-year-old man has arrived with a gradual swelling on the left side of his face persisting for two weeks. He had a prior incident of trauma involving wood, which occurred two months ago. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the nasal passages and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass within the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. Examination of a tissue sample obtained via biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, with positive staining observed using PAS and GMS methods. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis. GMS positive confirms this.

It is fungal infection which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs. 

Other Options:

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: This is a term historically used to describe aggressive midline facial granulomatous diseases, often linked to conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). It does not fit the biopsy findings or clinical scenario described here.

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Although the biopsy indicates the presence of a foreign body granuloma, the positive PAS and GMS staining suggests a fungal etiology, which is characteristic of Phycomycosis.

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: This is associated with IgG4-related disease, which presents with different clinical and histopathological findings, not typically involving PAS and GMS positive fungal elements.

Educational Objective:

Phycomycosis should be considered in patients with a history of trauma, swelling, and positive fungal stains (PAS and GMS), particularly if they have underlying conditions like diabetes or immunosuppression.

questions.text: What are the air cells located at the anterior most part of the anterior ethmoidal sinus called?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

 

The Agger nasi cells are the anterior-most air cells of the anterior ethmoid air cells. They are situated just above the attachment of the middle turbinate, making them critical landmarks in sinus surgery due to their proximity to the frontal sinus drainage pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulla ethmoidalis largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus

 

Option B. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell. They are significant due to their proximity to the optic nerve and the sphenoid sinus, posing a risk during sinus surgery.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor. Haller cells can impact the drainage of the maxillary sinus and are important to consider in imaging and surgical planning for sinus issues.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Agger nasi is the anterior-most air cells of anterior ethmoid air cells.
  • Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest air cells in ethmoidal air sinus
  • Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cells
  • Haller cells are ethmoid air cells that extend into the floor of the orbit and can affect the integrity and drainage of the maxillary sinus

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 152, 153

questions.text: Which ligament connects the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the 2nd metatarsal?(INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lisfranc

 

Explanation:

 

The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal.

 

The ligament that connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal is called the "Lisfranc ligament".

 

The Lisfranc ligament is a strong band of fibrous tissue that connects the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the second metatarsal bone in the foot. It is named after Jacques Lisfranc, a French surgeon who described amputations through this region during the Napoleonic Wars. The Lisfranc joint complex also includes the articulation between the other cuneiform bones and the metatarsals, as well as the tarsometatarsal ligaments and interosseous ligaments. The Lisfranc ligament is important for maintaining stability of the midfoot and for transferring forces from the hindfoot to the forefoot during walking and running. Injuries to the Lisfranc joint can result in significant disability and may require surgery to repair or stabilize the joint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chopart Ligament: Chopart's ligament is not a well-known ligament in the foot. The term "Chopart joint" typically refers to the midtarsal joint, which includes the articulation between the talus and navicular (talocalcaneonavicular joint) and the calcaneus and cuboid (calcaneocuboid joint). Ligaments associated with these joints help maintain their stability.

 

Option B. Spring Ligament: The spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus to the navicular bone. It is a vital structure for supporting the arch of the foot and preventing its collapse.

 

Option D. Deltoid Ligament: The deltoid ligament is located on the medial side of the ankle joint. It is a complex ligament that attaches to the medial malleolus of the tibia and connects to various tarsal bones, such as the talus, calcaneus, and navicular. The deltoid ligament plays a significant role in stabilizing the ankle joint and preventing excessive eversion (outward rolling) of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lisfranc ligament is specifically associated with the connection between the medial cuneiform and the base of the 2nd metatarsal.
