It is a strong ligament that helps stabilize the midfoot and prevents dislocation of the tarsometatarsal (TMT) joints. Injury to this ligament is commonly referred to as a Lisfranc injury, which can result from traumatic events like falls or sports injuries.

questions.text: The image given shows a patient who has undergone total laryngectomy due to laryngeal cancer. Identify the method of voice generation for this patient, as depicted in the provided image.(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tracheoesophageal prosthesis

 

The voice production modality depicted in the image is tracheoesophageal voice prosthesis.

 

The extended air from the trachea is diverted to the esophagus through a device that connects the trachea and esophagus in tracheoesophageal prosthesis. It also has a one-way valve that keeps food from entering into the trachea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrolarynx: Is a vibrating instrument that emits a low-pitched sound in the hypopharynx. The palate, tongue, and teeth then articulate it.

 

Option B. Chicago implant: Is a type of hearing aid.

 

Option D. Esophageal speech: The patient is trained to swallow air and slowly release it into the pharynx. 6-10 words can be spoken in a rough manner before re-swallowing the air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheoesophageal prosthesis is a common and effective method for voice restoration following total laryngectomy. It relies on a surgically implanted device that directs air into the esophagus where vibrations are created for speech, significantly enhancing the quality of life for patients who have lost their natural voice box.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to the area marked green in the image below? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Opponens pollicis

 

Explanation:

 

The palmar aspect of the first metacarpal is the area marked in the image. At this location, the opponens pollicis muscle inserts.

 

  • Opponens pollicis:
  • Origin: Crest of the trapezium and flexor retinaculum
  • Insertion: Whole length of the lateral border and adjoining lateral half of the palmar aspect of the first metacarpal.
  • Action: Flexes the metacarpal bone of the thumb.

 

The image below shows various intrinsic muscles of the hand.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor Pollicis Longus: Abductor pollicis longus is not directly attached to the first metacarpal. It originates from the posterior surface of the ulna and radius and inserts into the base of the first metacarpal bone. Its primary action is to abduct the thumb away from the palm.

 

Option B. Palmar Interossei: The palmar interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones in the palm of the hand. They are responsible for adducting the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They are not directly attached to the first metacarpal.

 

Option D. Flexor Pollicis Brevis: The flexor pollicis brevis muscle has two heads: the superficial head and the deep head. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum, while the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones.

  • Both heads of the flexor pollicis brevis insert into the base of the first metacarpal bone.
  • The main action of the flexor pollicis brevis is to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The opponens pollicis muscle originates from the flexor retinaculum and the Crest of the trapezium bone. It inserts into the first metacarpal bone.
  • The primary action of the opponens pollicis is to oppose the thumb, allowing for the grasping and pinching movements of the thumb.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures does not form part of the laryngeal skeleton? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation

 

The structure marked as 'A', is the hyoid bone, which is not a part of the laryngeal skeleton.

 

The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located at the base of the tongue. While it is not considered a part of the larynx itself.

 

The structures marked in the image are:

 

A - Hyoid bone

B - Thyroid cartilage

C - Epiglottis

D - Cricoid cartilage

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid Cartilage: The thyroid cartilage is a large, shield-shaped cartilage in the larynx. It forms the prominent Adam's apple in the front of the neck and plays a role in sound production.

 

Option C. Epiglottis: The epiglottis is a leaf-shaped cartilage  which belongs to larynx located at the base of the tongue. Its primary function is to prevent food and liquids from entering the airway (trachea) during swallowing.

 

Option D. Cricoid Cartilage: The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped cartilage located just below the thyroid cartilage. It is the only complete ring of cartilage in the larynx and provides structural support to the airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A set of cartilages that are joined by ligaments and fibrous membranes make up the laryngeal skeleton:

 

  • Hyaline cartilage: The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages
  • Elastic cartilage: The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage.

questions.text: Which of the following is a negative acute phase reactants ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albumin

 

Negative acute phase reactants are substances whose serum concentrations decrease in response to systemic inflammation. Albumin is one of the well-recognized negative acute phase reactants. Its levels fall during acute phase response as resources are shifted to produce more critical positive reactants that help in the defense and repair processes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haptoglobin: This is a positive acute phase reactant, which increases in response to inflammation.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Also a positive acute phase reactant, often increases in states of inflammation and infection.

 

Option D. C-reactive protein: A classic positive acute phase reactant, it increases dramatically in response to inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following muscles contribute to the formation of the structure marked in the image except: (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2nd Palmar interossei

 

The dorsal digital extension of the middle finger is the structure indicated in the picture. The middle finger's dorsal digital extension is not aided by the palmar interossei because they do not attach to the middle finger.

 

The palmar interossei muscles are also located between the metacarpal bones but are found on the palmar side of the hand. Their primary function is to adduct the fingers. Unlike the dorsal interossei, the palmar interossei insert only into the bases of the proximal phalanges and do not extend to the dorsal digital expansion. Therefore, the 2nd palmar interosseous does not contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Extensor hoods, also known as "dorsal digital expansions," are formed when the tendons of the extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus muscles cross over the dorsal aspect of the digits and extend over the proximal phalanges. These hoods are connected by the tendons of the extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and extensor pollicis brevis muscles.

 

 

 

The dorsal digital expansion, also known as the extensor hood or extensor expansion, is a complex aponeurotic structure found on the dorsal aspect of each finger. It serves as the insertion point for certain tendons and allows the extensor tendons to provide extension at all three finger joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd Dorsal interossei: The dorsal interossei muscles are located between the metacarpal bones and are primarily responsible for the abduction of the fingers. There are four dorsal interossei in the hand. The tendons of the dorsal interossei insert into the bases of the proximal phalanges and into the dorsal digital expansion. Therefore, the 2nd dorsal interosseous does contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Option B. Lumbricals: The lumbricals are four small muscles in the hand that arise from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons. Their primary function is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints. The tendons of the lumbricals insert into the dorsal digital expansion on the radial sides of the fingers. Hence, lumbricals do contribute to the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: The extensor digitorum muscle originates from the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. It extends down the forearm and sends tendons to the fingers. These tendons attach to the dorsal digital expansion and primarily facilitate the extension of the fingers. Thus, the extensor digitorum directly contributes to the formation of the dorsal digital expansion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dorsal digital expansion plays a key role in extending the finger joints and is formed by the integration of tendons from several muscles, excluding the 2nd Palmar interossei, which primarily functions in adduction and does not extend to the dorsal side of the fingers.

questions.text: AIDS-defining malignancies include all except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Melanoma

 

Melanoma, on the other hand, is a type of skin cancer primarily associated with UV exposure and is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. Although people with HIV/AIDS might have a higher risk of developing melanoma due to their immunocompromised state, it is not specifically used to define AIDS.

 

AIDS-defining malignancies are specific types of cancer that are more likely to occur in people with AIDS. These cancers are used in the clinical definition of AIDS because they are directly associated with the immunosuppression caused by the HIV virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kaposi's sarcoma: This cancer is caused by Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and is one of the most common AIDS-defining cancers. It manifests as vascular tumors that can appear on the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Invasive cervical carcinoma: This cancer is linked to the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) and is considered an AIDS-defining condition due to the increased risk in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Particularly the diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma, are common in AIDS patients due to the compromised immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanoma is not considered an AIDS-defining malignancy, unlike Kaposi's sarcoma, invasive cervical carcinoma, and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

choices.text: Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole
Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin
Candida albicans - Amphotericin B
Candida Krusei– Fluconazole

questions.text: Identify the correct 'organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant' pair: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Candida Krusei- Fluconazole

 

Candida Krusei is known to be intrinsically resistant to fluconazole, which is a widely used antifungal agent. This resistance is due to the specific genetic and biochemical characteristics of C. Kruse, which include efflux pumps that actively expel the drug and alterations in the target enzyme of fluconazole, making it less effective.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Aspergillus Niger - Voriconazole: Aspergillus Niger is not intrinsically resistant to voriconazole; in fact, voriconazole is one of the treatments of choice for Aspergillus infections.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus - Micafungin: Aspergillus fumigatus is sensitive to echinocandins, including micafungin. It is not intrinsically resistant to this drug.

 

Option C. Candida albicans - Amphotericin B: Candida albicans is sensitive to amphotericin B, which is a broad-spectrum antifungal with a wide range of activity against various fungal species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida Krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

choices.text: First degree of heart block

questions.text: Disappearance of loud S1 in mitral stenosis occurs in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild MS.

 

Loud S1 can be heard in mild MS also because loud S1 does not depend on severity of MS.

 

Loud S1 is one of the auscultatory hallmarks of MS, however it can be attenuated in a variety of conditions:

 

  • Associated MR
  • Long PR (first degree heart block)
  • CCF
  • Severe AR- regurgitant jet may impinge on AML
  • Calcified valve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Here, the prolonged PR interval delays the closure of the mitral valve relative to ventricular contraction, often softening or eliminating the loud S1.

 

Option B. AR (Aortic Regurgitation): The regurgitant flow in aortic regurgitation can prevent the mitral valve leaflets from closing tightly and sharply, thus softening the S1.

 

Option C. Calcified valve: Calcification of the mitral valve leads to stiffening of the leaflets, which inhibits their rapid movement and thus reduces the intensity of S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically present unless there is an associated condition that affects the mobility or timing of the mitral valve leaflet closure, such as calcification, regurgitation in other valves, or disturbances in electrical conduction that affect heart rhythm

questions.text: Match the following muscles with their action at shoulder joint: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

 

A. Latissimus dorsi: This muscle is known as the "stand at ease" muscle, the "climbers muscle," and the "swimmers muscle." It originates from the back and inserts into the front between two major muscles. When it contracts, it causes backward movement, extension, adduction, and medial rotation of the shoulder. Therefore, its action is extension with medial rotation (Action 2).

 

B. Supraspinatus: Located above the spine of the scapula, the supraspinatus muscle, when it contracts, moves the arm away from the midline, which is known as abduction. Hence, its action is abduction (Action 3).

 

C. Infraspinatus: This muscle originates from the back and rotates the arm outward when it contracts, causing lateral rotation. Thus, its action is lateral rotation (Action 4).

 

D. Pectoralis Major (sternal head): Originating from the midline (sternum and clavicle) and inserting into the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus, this muscle, when contracted, causes movement to the front (flexion). Therefore, its action is flexion (Action 1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Latissimus dorsi is responsible for extension with medial rotation.
  • Supraspinatus is responsible for abduction.
  • Infraspinatus is responsible for lateral rotation.
  • Pectoralis Major (sternal head) is responsible for flexion.

questions.text: Definition of PUO includes all of the following except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Undiagnosed after one week of investigation

 

The correct answer is C because the definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO) does not specify that the fever must remain undiagnosed for only one week. According to the established criteria for diagnosing PUO, the investigation can be longer and more thorough before labeling a fever as PUO. The criteria include a fever exceeding 38.3°C on at least two occasions, persisting for more than three weeks, and a diagnosis that remains uncertain after comprehensive history taking, physical examinations, and routine investigations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fever persisting for more than 3 weeks: This is incorrect because it is a part of the definition of PUO, where the fever must last for more than three weeks.

 

Option B. Immunocompromised status should be ruled out: This is incorrect  as a choice because being non-immunocompromised is a criterion in the diagnosis of PUO, which means any immunocompromised status should indeed be ruled out.

 

Option D. Temperature more than 38.3°C: This is also incorrect as it is part of the criteria, where the temperature must be more than 38.3°C on multiple occasions to consider it as PUO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Criteria for diagnosis of PUO:

 

  • Fever > 38.3 degrees C (101° F) on 2 occasions.
  • Duration > 3 weeks.
  • Not immunocompromised state.
  • Diagnosis not certain after history, physical examination and routine and obligatory investigations.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-dsDNA antibodies

 

The patient exhibits symptoms including erythematous lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin, arthralgia, and breathlessness, which are characteristic of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). The rash described is typical of an SLE rash and not dermatomyositis, which presents with rashes over the knuckles known as Gottron's papules.

 

For diagnosing SLE, anti-dsDNA antibodies are very useful due to their high specificity. Although their sensitivity is relatively low (30-50%), the specificity is very high (>90-95%), making them reliable markers for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are also associated with disease activity in SLE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antihistone antibodies: These are primarily associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, not classic SLE.

 

Option C. Anticentromere antibodies: These are typically seen in limited forms of scleroderma, particularly CREST syndrome, and are not associated with SLE.

 

Option D. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): While ANA is a good initial screening test for SLE due to its high sensitivity, it lacks specificity. ANA can be positive in a variety of autoimmune conditions, thus it is not as specific as anti-dsDNA antibodies for diagnosing SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for diagnosing Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), despite their moderate sensitivity.

questions.text: Below is a radioactive scan for thyroid pathology. which of the following is the most probable diagnosis: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypersecreting Adenoma

 

Image findings are suggestive of hypersecreting adenoma.

 

  1. Increased uptake in the right lobe at the thyroid
  2. Suppressed uptake in left lobe of thyroid

 

These findings are highly suggestive of a hypersecreting adenoma. This condition occurs when a benign tumor in the thyroid gland produces thyroid hormone independently of the normal regulatory mechanisms, leading to an overactive area (hot spot) in one part of the thyroid, with suppression of activity in the rest of the gland due to negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: Incorrect as this type of cancer typically presents with a "cold nodule," which shows reduced or no uptake on a radioactive scan. The scan shows no areas of reduced uptake indicative of a cold nodule.

 

Option C. Grave’s disease: Incorrect because Grave's disease generally causes a diffuse increase in uptake across the entire thyroid gland due to widespread stimulation of thyroid tissue. The scan does not show diffuse uptake, which rules out Grave's disease.

 

Option D. Lateral aberrant thyroid: Incorrect as this condition involves ectopic thyroid tissue that might appear as functioning thyroid tissue outside the normal location. The scan does not indicate any ectopic thyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypersecreting adenoma in the thyroid is characterized by increased radioactive uptake in one area of the thyroid with suppression in other areas, reflecting independent hormone production from the adenoma.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. The diagnostic criteria for DKA typically include:

 

  • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose levels greater than 250 mg/dL.
  • Ketosis: Presence of ketones in the blood or urine.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Indicated by an arterial pH of less than 7.3, a serum bicarbonate level of less than 15-18 mEq/L, and an anion gap greater than 12.

 

S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L is not a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Although potassium imbalance is common in DKA due to shifts between the intracellular and extracellular compartments, serum potassium levels are not used as a diagnostic criterion. Potassium levels can vary and might be normal, elevated, or decreased, depending on the stage of DKA and the treatment administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/dL: This is a diagnostic criterion for DKA as it confirms the presence of significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: This indicates metabolic acidosis, which is a key component of DKA.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: An increased anion gap signifies high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), which is typical in DKA due to the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of brachial plexus do not give any branches? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Divisions

 

Explanation:

 

The divisions in the brachial plexus do not give any branches.

 

However, the roots, trunks, and cords of the brachial plexus give out direct branches.

 

The brachial plexus is a complex network of nerves that originates from the ventral rami of the fifth cervical to the first thoracic spinal nerves (C5-T1). The brachial plexus is typically organized into five stages: roots, trunks, divisions, cords, and terminal branches.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Roots: The roots of the brachial plexus are the five ventral rami (C5-T1) that serve as the origin of the brachial plexus. These roots give off several branches:

 

  • C5 root can contribute to the dorsal scapular nerve.
  • C5 and C6 roots together give rise to the upper trunk, but before they merge, they can give off the nerve to the subclavius muscle (from C5 and C6).
  • C8 and T1 roots can contribute to the long thoracic nerve along with C7 root.

 

Option B. Cords: The cords are named based on their position relative to the axillary artery: lateral, medial, and posterior cords.

 

  • The lateral cord gives branches like the lateral pectoral nerve.
  • The medial cord gives branches like the medial pectoral, medial cutaneous nerve of arm, and medial cutaneous nerve of forearm.
  • The posterior cord provides branches like the upper subscapular, thoracodorsal, and lower subscapular nerves.

 

Option C. Trunks: There are three trunks in the brachial plexus: upper, middle, and lower.

 

  • The upper trunk is formed by the union of C5 and C6 roots and gives off the suprascapular nerve and the nerve to the omohyoid muscle.
  • The middle and lower trunks usually do not give any significant branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each trunk divides into two divisions: an anterior division and a posterior division. The divisions do not provide any branches.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks
Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units as single dose
Benzathine penicillin 12-24 million units for 21 days

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of late cardiovascular syphilis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks.

 

Late cardiovascular syphilis is a form of tertiary syphilis that typically requires intensive antibiotic treatment to effectively manage the disease. The recommended regimen for treating this condition involves the administration of Benzathine penicillin G at a dose of 2.4 million units administered intramuscularly once a week for a total of three weeks. This regimen is effective because it maintains a therapeutic level of penicillin in the blood over a prolonged period, which is necessary for eradicating the persistent Treponema pallidum bacteria responsible for syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

 

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland or another source. This excessive release results in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L: This option is incorrect. In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically high, usually greater than 40 mEq/L, due to the body's inability to excrete water appropriately, which leads to concentrated urine with high sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum sodium <135 mEq/L: This option is correct as SIADH commonly presents with hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) due to the dilution of blood sodium by the retained water.


Option C. Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg: This option is correct. In SIADH, urine osmolality is typically high because the kidneys are concentrating the urine inappropriately due to the persistent effect of ADH.

 

Option D. Patient can be clinically euvolemic: This option is correct. Patients with SIADH often appear clinically euvolemic (normal body fluid volume), as the retained water is distributed evenly throughout the body without significant signs of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

 

The first-line drugs for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are typically Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs), which include sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate. These drugs are considered core therapies and are often used together in what is known as "triple therapy."

 

Sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate are highly effective and commonly used in the treatment of RA. They form the backbone of conventional synthetic DMARDs (csDMARDs).

 

Azathioprine, on the other hand, is not a first-line drug for RA management. While it is used in some autoimmune conditions, it is not as effective for RA as the other mentioned drugs. Its efficacy is lower, and it is not commonly included in the standard RA treatment regimens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulfasalazine: This drug is a part of the core therapies for RA and is commonly used as a first-line treatment. It is known for its effectiveness and is often used in combination with other DMARDs.

 

Option B. Hydroxychloroquine: Another key first-line drug for RA, hydroxychloroquine is widely used due to its efficacy and relatively favorable safety profile. It is often part of the triple therapy regimen.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is considered the cornerstone of RA treatment and is usually the first drug prescribed. It is highly effective and forms the basis of most RA treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Azathioprine is not a first-line drug for the management of rheumatoid arthritis; the primary first-line drugs are sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate.

 

Note -

 

  • Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine are considered safe for use during pregnancy and are preferred in the management of RA among pregnant patients.
  • Azathioprine is also somewhat safe during pregnancy, but it is not as effective for RA, so it is less preferred compared to Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine.
  • Methotrexate and Leflunomide are not safe for use during pregnancy and should be avoided due to potential risks to the developing fetus.

 

Additional Information:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis management: Range of biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (bDMARDs) and targeted synthetic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (tsDMARDs).

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The occipitotemporal fracture in the clinical scenario is suggestive of involvement of the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, which are tested by pressing on the uvula, which is indicated as 2 in the image.

 

The jugular foramen is located between the lower border of the petrous part of the temporal bone and the condylar part of the occipital bone. As the investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region, along with the history of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, are suggestive of injury to the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve passing through the jugular foramen.

 

Unilateral lesions of IX and X cranial nerves are commonly caused by skull-base fractures, strokes, or tumors.

 

Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve examination include:

 

  • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula(marked as 2 in the given image) at rest and with phonation ("aah").
  • The pharyngeal (gag") reflex is evaluated by stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a sterile, blunt object (e.g., tongue blade)

 

Individuals who have a proximal unilateral vagus nerve lesion report having trouble swallowing. On the affected side, the soft palate muscles will be weak. When the patient is asked to utter "aah," for example, an attempt to elevate the soft palate voluntarily will demonstrate a deficit in that side's ability to do so. Due to the palatal muscles' unopposed action on that side, there will also be a deviation of the uvula to the typical side along with this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. 1: This area does not relate to the glossopharyngeal or vagus nerves, which are crucial in the described symptoms.

 

Option. C. 3: This area is likely distant from the jugular foramen where nerves IX and X pass, thus not directly involved with the symptoms presented.

 

Option. D. 4: This lower section of the brain and skull does not typically involve the pathways or exit points of the cranial nerves implicated in swallowing and speech functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of occipitotemporal fractures with symptoms of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, it is critical to assess the function of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves, as these are commonly affected by such injuries. Testing should focus on the functionality of the palate and uvula where these nerves can be clinically evaluated.

choices.text: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.text: During the process of conducting a caloric test, what kind of nystagmus should one anticipate when using cold water irrigation?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side

 

In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side.

 

Fitzgerald-Hallpike test or bithermal caloric test procedure:

 

  • Patient is made to lie supine with the head tilted 30° forward so that the horizontal canal is vertical.

 

 

  • Irrigation stimulates the lateral/ horizontal semicircular canal which produces horizontal nystagmus.
  • Cold water induces nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side (remember mnemonic COWS: cold-opposite, warm-same)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side: This option is incorrect for cold water irrigation. Cold water causes the fluid in the horizontal semicircular canal to move in a way that induces nystagmus towards the opposite side, not the same side.

 

Option B. Vertical nystagmus towards the same side and Option D. Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side: Vertical nystagmus does not occur in caloric testing, as this test specifically stimulates the horizontal semicircular canal, inducing horizontal nystagmus. Vertical nystagmus is generally associated with different pathologies and is not a result of standard caloric testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The caloric test, particularly when using cold water, is designed to stimulate the horizontal semicircular canal, resulting in horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side. This test is critical for evaluating unilateral weaknesses in the vestibular system and helps in diagnosing conditions affecting balance and spatial orientation.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, page No. 45

choices.text: Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries
Sphenopalatine artery
Greater palatine artery
Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the external carotid artery in Kiesselbach's plexus?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Arterial supply of the nose:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System -

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: Incorrect because the sphenopalatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery (itself a branch of the external carotid artery), contributes to the arterial supply of Kiesselbach's plexus. It gives rise to the nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Incorrect because the septal branch of the greater palatine artery, also a branch of the maxillary artery from the external carotid system, supplies the nasal septum and participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: Incorrect as this artery, a branch of the facial artery (which stems from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to the Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

 

Educational objective

 

Kiesselbach's plexus -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: Identify the nerve passing around the marked structure: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common peroneal nerve

 

The structure marked in the image is the fibula's neck.

 

The common peroneal nerve supplies motor fibers to the muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg, including the fibularis longus and fibularis brevis muscles, which evert the foot and plantarflex the ankle joint. It also provides sensory fibers to the skin over the lateral aspect of the leg and dorsum of the foot.

 

Injuries to the common peroneal nerve can occur due to trauma or compression, and can result in weakness or paralysis of the muscles it innervates, as well as sensory loss over the affected area. Common peroneal nerve injuries can be treated with conservative measures such as physiotherapy or surgery in severe cases.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sural nerve: The sural nerve is a sensory nerve in the calf region. It is formed by branches from both the common peroneal and tibial nerves. The sural nerve provides sensation to the posterolateral aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot. It runs more distally in the leg and is not closely associated with the neck of the fibula.

 

Option C. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve is another major branch of the sciatic nerve. After the division of the sciatic nerve, the tibial nerve continues its course in the posterior compartment of the leg, supplying muscles there and then continuing into the foot. It is primarily responsible for plantar flexion of the foot and toe flexion. The tibial nerve does not have a close relation with the neck of the fibula as it runs more medially in the leg.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve originates from the lumbar plexus and supplies the anterior compartment of the thigh. It is responsible for hip flexion and knee extension. This nerve is located in the anterior aspect of the thigh, far away from the neck of the fibula, and has no direct relation with it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Common peroneal nerve (also known as common fibular nerve), a significant branch of the sciatic nerve, follows a course along the thigh's posterior compartment and wraps around the fibula's neck, making it susceptible to injury. After encircling the fibula, it splits into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves, which innervate the leg's lateral and anterior compartments and contribute sensory functions to parts of the foot.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derivatives of NCC (Neural crest cells),  except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinal pigment membrane

 

The retinal pigment membrane (or retinal pigment epithelium, RPE) develops from the ectoderm of the optic cup, which is an outgrowth of the developing brain, and not from neural crest cells. The neural retina and RPE both develop from the neuroectoderm of the optic vesicle, making them extensions of the central nervous system rather than neural crest derivatives.
 

Neural crest cells (NCCs)

Ciliary muscles

Melanocytes

Ciliary ganglion

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ciliary muscles: The ciliary muscles develop from neural crest cells that contribute to the development of structures in the eye.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: Melanocytes throughout the body, including those in the skin and iris, are derived from neural crest cells that migrate from the neural tube during embryonic development.

 

Option D. Ciliary ganglion: The ciliary ganglion, a parasympathetic ganglion associated with the eye, is derived from neural crest cells. Neural crest cells give rise to all parasympathetic ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural crest cells give rise to diverse structures including melanocytes, parasympathetic ganglia (including ciliary ganglion), and components of the eye (like ciliary muscles), but the retinal pigment epithelium develops from the optic cup neuroectoderm.

questions.text: What is the normal prostate volume in a healthy adult male? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20cc

 

Explanation:

 

The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

 

The volume of the prostate gland in normal adult males can vary depending on age and other factors. However, on average, the volume of the prostate gland in an adult male is around 20-30 cubic centimeters (cc) or milliliters (mL).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical volume of the prostate in a normal adult male is around 20cc

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in medicine ward with fever. What could be the possible diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Image shows typical biphasic illness with initial leptospiremic phase followed by immune phase.

 

Other illness that shows biphasic pattern include measles, Tick borne encephalitis virus, rarely Zika virus.

 

Modified Faine Criteria is used for diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monophasic illness with predominant CNS and multisystem involvement.

 

Option C. Undulant fever presenting with PUO, muscle pain, thoracic backpain

 

Option D. Enteric fever causes step ladder pattern of fever.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a biphasic fever pattern, especially when supported by epidemiologic data pointing to possible exposure to contaminated water or animals. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as Weil's disease, which can lead to severe renal and hepatic issues.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Leptospirosis/Chap 184

choices.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not related anteriorly to the third part of the duodenum? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fundus and body of Gall bladder

 

Explanation:

 

The fundus and body of the gallbladder are not typically considered anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The gallbladder is situated more to the right and superior to the duodenum, so it is not directly in front of it.

 

Note - The junction of the first and second parts of the duodenum lies posterior to the neck of the gallbladder. The anterior relations of the third segment of the duodenum comprise the Superior mesenteric vessels, the Root of the mesentery, and Loops of the jejunum

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Superior mesenteric vessels: The superior mesenteric vessels, which include the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and superior mesenteric vein (SMV), are anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum. The SMA runs just posterior to the third part of the duodenum, and the SMV is typically located to the right of the SMA and also in front of the duodenum.

 

Option B) Loops of jejunum:  Loops of the jejunum, which are part of the small intestine, can lie anterior to the third part of the duodenum. The small intestine, including the jejunum, is positioned in the abdominal cavity, and its loops can be found in close proximity to the duodenum.

 

Option C) Root of mesentery: The root of the mesentery is an extension of the peritoneum that connects the small intestine (including the jejunum and ileum) to the posterior abdominal wall. It passes in front of the third part of the duodenum as it continues to the jejunum and ileum. Therefore, it is an anterior relation of the third part of the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ribs

 

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the para-axial mesoderm. In the 33-hour chick embryo, the para-axial mesoderm is situated on each side of the neural tube and notochord. This mesoderm divides into segments known as somites. Somites further differentiate into sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.
  • The sclerotome, derived from the somites, gives rise to the vertebrae and ribs. The para-axial mesoderm is responsible for forming these segmented structures, essential components of the axial skeleton.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kidney: Incorrect. The kidney is derived from the intermediate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Dorsal root ganglion: Incorrect. The dorsal root ganglion is derived from neural crest cells, which are separate from the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option C. Parietal pleura: Incorrect. The parietal pleura is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The para-axial mesoderm forms somites, which give rise to the vertebrae and ribs.

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of these options is not a division originating from the external carotid artery within Kiesselbach's plexus? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries

 

Anterior and posterior ethmoidal artery are branches of ophthalmic artery which in turn is a branch of internal carotid artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphenopalatine artery: This artery is correctly identified as a branch of the maxillary artery, which itself is a major branch of the external carotid artery. It contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus by providing the septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option C. Greater palatine artery: Also a branch of the maxillary artery, the septal branch of the greater palatine artery participates in forming Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Option D. Septal branch of superior labial artery: This artery, a branch of the facial artery (which originates from the external carotid artery), is part of the blood supply to Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ARTERIAL SUPPLY OF THE NOSE:

 

Internal carotid system -

 

  • Branches of ophthalmic artery
  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery

 

External Carotid System –

 

  • Sphenopalatine artery (branch of maxillary artery) gives nasopalatine and posterior medial nasal branches.
  • Septal branch of greater palatine artery (branch of maxillary artery).
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of facial artery).

 

KIESSELBACH'S PLEXUS -

 

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of nasal septum to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach's plexus.

 

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of greater palatine

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: A young woman, aged 25, presented with hearing impairment that emerged shortly after her initial pregnancy. Provided below is her audiometry findings. What could be the potential diagnosis for this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otosclerosis

 

Hearing loss that developed shortly after the first pregnancy along with Carhart's notch seen in the audiogram is suggestive of otosclerosis.

 

Interpretation of the given audiogram:

 

  • Blue color indicates the left ear.
  • x indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB and hence AC is abnormal. So it indicates conductive deafness.
  • ] indicates BC and threshold is <25dB. A characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz called Carhart’s notch is seen.
  • The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, left-sided otosclerosis is the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.

 

Option B: Meniere's disease shows a low-frequency loss in the SNHL curve.

 

 

Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss - PTA shows a characteristic Acoustic dip at 4000 Hz (Boiler’s Notch).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following types of joints is not formed by the bone shown in the image?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The image shows a thoracic vertebra, identifiable by its long spinous process, body, and superior and inferior articular facets. Thoracic vertebrae participate in forming several types of joints but do not form synchondroses. A synchondrosis is a primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage, which is not present in the thoracic vertebra.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: Incorrect. Syndesmosis joints are formed where two bones are connected by a ligament. An example related to the vertebrae would be the interspinous ligament connecting adjacent spinous processes.

 

Option C. Plane joint: Incorrect. Plane joints are formed by thoracic vertebrae, such as the costovertebral and costotransverse joints, where the ribs articulate with the thoracic vertebrae.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Incorrect. Symphysis joints are formed between the vertebral bodies of adjacent thoracic vertebrae via the intervertebral discs, which are composed of fibrocartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracic vertebrae do not form synchondrosis (primary cartilaginous) joints; they are involved in forming plane joints, syndesmosis, and symphysis joints.
